message_1: Find the residue of the function f(z) = z^3 / (z - i)(z - 2) at the pole z=i.
message_2:
To find the residue of the function f(z) = z^3 / (z - i)(z - 2) at the pole z = i, we can use the following formula for simple poles:

Residue = lim (z -> i) [(z - i) * f(z)]

So, we have:

Residue = lim (z -> i) [(z - i) * (z^3 / (z - i)(z - 2))]

The (z - i) term cancels out:

Residue = lim (z -> i) [z^3 / (z - 2)]

Now, we can substitute z = i:

Residue = (i^3) / (i - 2)

Residue = (-i) / (i - 2)

To get rid of the imaginary unit in the denominator, we can multiply the numerator and denominator by the complex conjugate of the denominator:

Residue = (-i) * (i + 2) / ((i - 2)(i + 2))

Residue = (-i) * (i + 2) / (i^2 - 4)

Residue = (-i) * (i + 2) / (-1 - 4)

Residue = (-i) * (i + 2) / (-5)

Now, we can distribute the -i:

Residue = (-i^2 - 2i) / (-5)

Residue = (1 - 2i) / (-5)

Finally, we can divide both the real and imaginary parts by -5:

Residue = -1/5 + (2/5)i

So, the residue of the function f(z) = z^3 / (z - i)(z - 2) at the pole z = i is -1/5 + (2/5)i.
